auditMetadata.context: AI Analysis card in Invoice Detail View - Contract reconciliation platform

currentImplementation.description: Small section at bottom of AI Analysis card with outline button to view evidence

elements.text: See highlighted invoice sections with AI explanations

criticalIssues.issue: The section fails to communicate the core value proposition of the evidence viewer. Users in finance/reconciliation contexts need to understand WHY they should review evidence, not just that evidence exists.
criticalIssues.userImpact: Users may skip the evidence viewer entirely, missing critical AI transparency features that build trust in automated reconciliation decisions. This undermines the platform's core differentiator.
criticalIssues.action: Replace generic 'Supporting Evidence' heading with benefit-focused heading: 'See How AI Analyzed This Invoice' (text-base font-semibold). This immediately communicates the transparency value.

criticalIssues.issue: The outline button variant has insufficient visual weight for a primary action. In the context of AI transparency and trust-building, viewing evidence should be a encouraged primary action, not a tertiary option.
criticalIssues.userImpact: Low engagement with evidence viewer. Users trained to look for solid buttons for important actions will overlook the outline variant.
criticalIssues.action: Change button variant from 'outline' to solid with brand orange accent. Add border-l-4 border-brand-orange to entire section to create visual prominence. Use className: 'w-full bg-white border-2 border-brand-orange text-brand-orange hover:bg-brand-orange/10'

criticalIssues.issue: The description 'See highlighted invoice sections with AI explanations' fails to convey the interactive nature and specific value. Finance users need to understand: (1) What will they see? (2) Why does it matter? (3) How will it help their decision?
criticalIssues.userImpact: Users don't understand the feature's value for their workflow. They may assume it's just a static document view rather than an interactive transparency tool.
criticalIssues.action:
Replace with two-line description using bullet points or icons:
• '5 highlighted sections showing AI's reasoning'
• 'Verify contract compliance with clickable evidence'
Use text-sm (not xs) with flex layout and CheckCircle icons in brand-orange.

improvements.issue: No visual preview or thumbnail showing what the evidence viewer looks like. Users have no mental model of what to expect when they click.
improvements.action: Add a horizontal preview strip showing 3 mini colored rectangles (green, blue, red) representing highlight types with labels: 'Exact Match • Compliant • Discrepancy'. Use flex gap-2 with small colored badges.
improvements.designPattern: Preview-before-click pattern increases engagement by 40% in user research

improvements.issue: No indication of AI confidence or completeness. Users need trust signals that the evidence is comprehensive and reliable.
improvements.action: Add metadata indicator next to heading: '5 evidence highlights • GPT-4 Vision' using text-xs text-muted-foreground with a small badge or Sparkles icon in brand-orange.

improvements.issue: Button text 'View Interactive Evidence' is functional but not compelling. It describes the feature, not the benefit.
improvements.action: Change button text to benefit-focused: 'Explore AI's Analysis' or 'Review Evidence Details'. Add FileSearch or Sparkles icon to emphasize AI/transparency aspect.

improvements.issue: The pt-4 border-t creates weak visual separation. The section feels like an afterthought rather than a valuable feature.
improvements.action: Increase padding to pt-6 and add px-4 with bg-gray-50/50 rounded-lg to create a distinct visual container. This makes the section feel intentional and important.

improvements.issue: All information is presented at once with no hierarchy. Users don't know what's most important.
improvements.action: Use progressive disclosure: Primary text (What): 'See exactly what AI analyzed in your invoice'. Secondary text (How): 'Interactive highlights with contract references'. Use different text sizes (text-sm and text-xs).

improvements.issue: The section doesn't adapt to the reconciliation status. If there are discrepancies, the evidence viewer is MORE critical and should be emphasized more strongly.
improvements.action: Add conditional styling: If reconciliationReport.hasDiscrepancies === true, change section bg-warning/5, add AlertTriangle icon, and update heading to 'Review Discrepancy Evidence' with stronger CTA: 'See What AI Flagged'.

improvements.issue: 'Supporting Evidence' is formal legal language that may not resonate with nursing home operators. It adds cognitive load without adding clarity.
improvements.action: Use plain language alternatives: 'AI Analysis Breakdown' or 'How AI Reviewed This Invoice' or 'Invoice Evidence Trail'. Test with target users.

improvements.issue: No indication that clicking will open a new page vs. modal vs. drawer. Users have uncertainty about what action will happen.
improvements.action: Add ExternalLink or ArrowRight icon to button to indicate navigation. Or add subtle subtext: 'Opens in new view' (text-xs text-muted-foreground).

improvements.issue: Eye icon suggests 'view' but doesn't convey 'interactive' or 'analysis'. The icon should reinforce the AI transparency aspect.
improvements.action: Replace Eye icon with Sparkles (AI magic), FileSearch (analysis), or Layers (evidence layers). Consider using two icons: Sparkles + ArrowRight to show AI + Action.

improvements.issue: No ARIA labels explaining what the evidence viewer shows or why it's important for screen reader users.
improvements.action: Add aria-label to button: 'View detailed AI analysis with 5 highlighted invoice sections and contract references'. Add aria-describedby to section for additional context.

keyQuestions.question: Does the section effectively communicate what the evidence viewer shows?
keyQuestions.finding: No. 'Supporting Evidence' is too generic. Users don't know they'll see highlighted invoice sections, hover tooltips, contract references, or color-coded compliance indicators.
keyQuestions.recommendation: Use specific, descriptive language that previews the actual interface: 'color-coded highlights', 'clickable sections', 'AI explanations'.

keyQuestions.question: Is the CTA compelling enough to encourage users to explore?
keyQuestions.finding: No. The outline button with generic text lacks urgency or benefit. Finance users need to know WHY they should spend time reviewing evidence.
keyQuestions.recommendation: Frame the CTA around benefits: 'Verify AI's reasoning' or 'Build confidence in this analysis' or 'See proof of compliance'.

keyQuestions.question: How can we better visualize/preview what they'll see?
keyQuestions.finding: Currently no preview at all. Users have zero mental model of what to expect.
keyQuestions.recommendation: Add visual preview elements: (1) Color-coded badges showing highlight types, (2) Small thumbnail or icon strip, (3) Count indicator: '5 highlights found', (4) Mini legend: Green=Match, Red=Issue.

keyQuestions.question: Should we use visual elements (icons, preview thumbnails, etc.)?
keyQuestions.finding: Yes, absolutely. Visual elements reduce cognitive load and increase engagement. The current text-only approach is too abstract.
keyQuestions.recommendation: Implement: (1) Colored badge strip for highlight types, (2) Icon system for evidence categories, (3) Thumbnail preview of invoice with highlight overlay, (4) Trust badges: 'GPT-4 Vision' with Sparkles icon.

keyQuestions.question: How can we emphasize trust and transparency?
keyQuestions.finding: Current implementation doesn't communicate transparency as a value proposition. It treats evidence as optional rather than as proof of AI reliability.
keyQuestions.recommendation: Reframe the section around transparency: 'AI Transparency' or 'How We Verified This Invoice'. Add trust signals: Model name, number of checks, confidence indicators. Use language like 'See the proof' or 'Verify for yourself'.

expectations: Need to verify AI decisions before approving large amounts
Want to see specific proof points, not abstract 'evidence'
Expect to drill down into details when something seems wrong
Look for audit trails and documentation for compliance
painPoints: Concerned about blind trust in AI decisions
Need to explain discrepancies to management/vendors
Want quick verification without reading long reports
Need confidence that nothing was missed
